title: Can we forgive British people for partition of India? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don't intend to adopt a lamenting tone but sadly we seem to somehow always find a scapegoat for our all our problems be it developmental, political and as is evident by this question, historical. It has been established as a fact based on historical evidence that pre British era India or the India before the plague that was East India Company was a subcontinent that was ruled by thousands of petty Maharajas, Rajas and Nawabs who were always at each other's throats for trivial reasons. The autocracy's bloated ego that used to swell with each "nazrana" or offerings from the nobility and the hollow words of flattery that flowed like perpetual rivers by courtiers and patronized poets resulted in these kingdoms becoming so feeble and inept that even a concubine's rhythmic, delicate dance move could break it apart. Opulence, hedonism and slavery to the luxuries of life had so engulfed the autocracy of that period that the hands that once held mighty swords and forged kingdoms out of blood and iron were ornately decorated with Henna and adorned with jewellery. It was in this period of vulnerability that the British entered India with shady intentions and consolidated their tentacles around the golden bird with such speed and efficiency as the world had never witnessed before and has not witnessed since. Despite having suffered unspeakable injustices at the hands of foreign invaders marauding as guides and helpers, we never quite learned to unite as a nation and face the common enemy. The caste issue was always bigger than the white skinned, strange speaking enemy that made people prostrate with the crack of his whip. Personal differences, petty quarrels, family disputes, tribes, religion, regions and even language could gather more support and unite people than the notion of confronting the true enemy that was destroying the nation before their very eyes. A Brahmin would not break bread with someone from a lower caste let alone a non Hindu, a Muslim would be more bothered about the length of his beard and whether his zenana was properly veiled or not, a Sikh would not work with a non Sikh. It were these conspicuous and glaring differences that were too obvious to ignore that had served as the most effective and lethal ammunition for the foreign invaders. The partition of 1947 was only the culmination of simmering tensions that had always existed. Indians had never quite got themselves around the notion of unity and national brotherhood which was the real cause, in my opinion, why India was cleaved into two parts. Pathetically, it didn’t just end there. With utter disregard for human life and human rights, a nation was pulled out prematurely and violently from the womb of unrest and turmoil in the late 20th century, a nation that has never seen prosperity and development since the day it was formed, Bangladesh. To make things worse, a tom and jerry show has ever since continued on the issue of Kashmir. Nobody gives a crap about what the Kashmiris want, what their opinion is. Nobody ever asks them, they are always told. More than 90% of our nation’s army is posted throughout Kashmir making life for the civilians there miserable and consequently turning the place into a breeding ground for insurgents and anti-social elements. We are a nation that thinks not with our brains but that which is the source of testosterone. We are a nation that needs a National Cleanliness Campaign to “create awareness” about hygiene. We are a nation where even today humans are treated worse than animals. We are a nation that has learned to speak English better than the mother tongue but still hasn’t learned to respect a queue. We are a nation that still elects criminals and mass murderers as its political leaders who then take decisions that impact not theirs but our own lives. We are a nation that looks for loopholes when the going gets tough. WE need to change this. Only WE can change the status quo. The last held elections in Delhi are evidence of the common man’s power. We need to exercise it. In the words of our nation’s father, we need to be the change we want to see.

I would. Maybe I shouldn't. Though they took a lot, they gave a lot too. The integration and unification of India (indirectly), the infrastructure that connects and binds the nation, the administration, the international exposure,... and the most important thing, which I am using right now, is the language that has made India communicate between its own regionally and linguistically different geographies.  Having said all that, the idea of the partition was NOT of the British and it was NOT the British who were solely responsible for the Partition of India. Who's idea it was, is an entirely different story. Though many a media stalwarts give (and prove) their own theories about why, how and who are responsible for the partion, I am of the opinion that the British only FACILITATED the partition which local political people/entities were more responsible for.
